2012 Mali Government
2012 Mali Government
Protesters surrounded the presidential palace, protesting the governments handling of the attacks by Tuareg rebels.  Protesters also blocked streets and burned tires, and retaliatory attacks against Tuareg property in the city were reported
Soldiers families gathered to protest the government's handling of the Tuareg rebels. Protesters also attacked the home and business of a Tuareg family.
Protests against the governments handling of the Tuareg rebellions took place in southern cities Segou and Sikasso.
Protests against the governments handling of the Tuareg rebellions took place in southern cities Segou and Sikasso.
Security forces dispersed an attempted protest against the arrest of two female rebel supporters.
Mutinous soldiers surrounded and began firing on the presidential palace in Bamako after seizing the Malian Radio-Television Office.  The soldiers claimed to be dissatisfied with Government handling of the Tuareg rebels and demanded new weapons with which to fight them.  They also began protesting in military bases in Kati and Gao.  The president was forced to flea.

They also began protesting in military bases in Kati and Gao.  The president was forced to flea.
14 ministers under custody of the military junta began a hunger strike to protest their detention.
About 1000 protesters from political parties and organizations, forming the FUDR staged a protest outside the stock exchange, demonstrating against the junta.  They called for a return of constitutional order.
Thousands of protesters organized by Mali's only opposition party in Parliament demonstrated in support of the Junta.  Their banners denounced President Toure, France, and the international community.  Protesters also turned away a plane carrying 5 West African heads of state by swarming the airport runway.
25,000 Christian and Muslim demonstrators gathered at the stadium in Bamako to stage a peace rally.
Political parties supporting the coup bussed in several hundred people to stage a pro-junta rally in a statdium in Bamako.
A protest was held in Northern Mali
A Swiss woman was kidnapped in Timbuktu by an Islamist group.
Soldiers loyal to the pre-junta government staged a countercoup in Bamako, first attempting to take the airport to fly in reinforcements.  Much of the fighting centered around the garrison at Kati, near Bamako.  The countercoup was defeated.

Students staged a protest after rumors circulated saying forces close to the junta had killed a student leader.  A spokesman denied the student had been killed.
Islamists, who have occupied Timbuktu since April, attacked an desecrated the tomb of Sidi Mahmoud Ben Amar, which is classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This has threatened to inflame tensions between the Islamists and residents of the city.
Residents of occupied Goa staged a protest against the Rebel and Islamists forces holding the city.  Five protesters were wounded.
Thousands of Malians staged a protest against the deal brokered between the junta, Diancounda Traore, and ECOWAS, claiming that it had not involved the Malian people. Protesters also broke into Traore's office and attacked him.  He was later taken, unconscious to a hospital.
Members of Ansar Dine destroyed a monument to those who died in the 1991 struggle against dictator Moussa Traore.
Residents of northern towns staged protests against the Islamist Ansar Dine and in support of the Secular MNLA.
Protesters gathered to demonstrate against the killing of municipal leader Idrissa Oumarou by an insurgent.  MNLA openned fire on the protesters, killing one and wounding several others.  The Islamists MUJAO took the opportunity to invade and seize the city.
Islamists attacked and destroyed three historic tombs of Muslim saints as well as a historic mosque.  The tombs are considered by UNESCO to be World Heritage Sites
Around 2000 protesters from Northern Mali staged a sit-in protest in Bamako against the Islamists who have taken over the north of the country.  Inparticular, th edemonstrated against Ansar Dine's destruction of sites in Timbuktu and the laying of landmines around Gao.
Between 250 and 500 Pro-coup demonstrators protested in Bamako against the ECOWAS meeting called to discuss solutions to the crisis in Mali.
Approximately 90 residents of Goundam staged a protest against occupying Islamists forces after Ansar Dine members whipped a woman carrying her baby for not wearing an adequate veil, injuring the child.  Islamists then went from house to house whipping the protesters.
Over 300 military wives marched in Bamako demanding to know the wereabouts of the soldiers who were arrested or disappeared after the March 22 coup.
Over 500 journalists marched in Bamako and went on a one day strike, protesting attacks on journalists by armed men believed to be linked to the junta that took power March 22.

CMA fighters announced that they had captured 19 Malian soldiers in fighting in Tessit; the Malian army did not confirm this number.
Gunmen attacked a UN vehicle near the Bamako airport, killing one peackeeper and wounding another.
Thousands of demonstrators marched in Bamako to support the government and express support for the peace agreement.
A UN convoy hit a land mine between the towns of Dire and Bar, wounding 3 peacekeepers; AQIM later claimed responsibility for the attack.
A rocket was fired into a wall at a MINUSMA base in Gao but caused no casualties; AQIM claimed the attack a few days later.
A haulier was kidnapped by an unknown group in the Gao region and his body was found two days later.
A civilian was killed after being fired on from a car.
A civilian was killed by gunmen.
Jihadists attacked a military base in the town of Misseni, killing a policeman.
Ansar Dine fighters attacked Malian soldiers in the town of Nara; 3 soliders and 9 Ansar Dine fighters were killed.
Ansar Dine fighters ransaked the town of Fakola, burning public buildings and the police station before being driven out by security forces.
Malian soldiers killed 3 terrorists in a search operation in the Sama forest near Fakola.
AQIM ambushed a UN patrol on the road to Goundam, killing 6 peacekeepers, wounding 5, and destroying two vehicles.
French special forces killed Ali Ag Wadossene, a leader of AQIM, and captured 2 others in an operation in the Kidal region.
Malian troops conducted two offensives in the Sikasso region to capture insurgents, including Ansar Diner fighters; the military reported that several jihadists were killed.
An army convoy was ambushed by fighters on the road between Nampala and Diabaly; 2 soldiers were killed and 5 were injured.
AQIM fighters on motorcycles attacked a security post of the Mali National Guard in Gourma-Rharouss and killed 11 soldiers.
FLM fighters attempted to attack a Sevare army base and Hotel Debo before entering the hotel Byblos, opening fire, and taking hostages; the resulting fighting and overnight  standoff killed 4 attackers, 4 soldiers, 4 UN workers, and a Malian driver.
Tuareg separatists attacked the village of Gaberi and killed 10 people; a source said it was retaliation in response to the beheading of a separatist by a pro-government group.
A military vehicle hit an IED near Diabozo, killing 3 soldiers.
Two gunmen opened fire on a police post at a busy bus station in Bamako, wounding a policeman and a civilian.
Two gunmen killed Aladji Sekou, an imam in the village of Barkerou who had refused jihadist attempts to recruit him.
Three days of fighting took place in the Kidal region between GATIA and the CMA; 23 CMA fighters were killed and GATIA took over the village of Anefis.
Three days of fighting took place in the Kidal region between GATIA and the CMA; 23 CMA fighters were killed and GATIA took over the village of Anefis.
Armed Tuareg nomads attacked a Songhai camp in northern Mali, provoking a counterattack the following day; theft and intercommuncal conflict motivated the attacks.
A vehicle in a UN convoy hit a land mine on a road 70 km east of Ansongo, and two UN peacekeepers were seriously injured.
Gunmen with automatic weapons attacked an army checkpoint outside Timbuktu; 2 soldiers were killed, 1 was injured, and 1 went missing.
Members of the Macina Liberation Front attacked a police post in Ouenkoro and killed an officer, after which they set fire to two vehicles and the residence of a local government official.
Officials in the Kidal region announced that fighting had resumed between Tuareg separatists and a pro-government militia; a spokesman for the alliance of Tuareg groups confirmed this and stated that the fighting was in self-defense after pro-government militia fighters moved on their positions.
Gunmen opened fire on the police station in Bih, killing two policemen and two civilians.
Tuareg separatists attacked a village in the Gao region, targeting the families of Tuaregs thought to be aligned with the government.
Jihadists entered the village of Dounapen brandishing black flags and killed 3 civilians, including a mayoral assistant.
Three members of the French special forces were injured in a landmine explosion in northern Mali.
A civilian convoy being escorted by security forces hit a roadside bomb west of Gao and was then attacked by jihadists, killing 6 civilians and wounding 1 civilian and one soldier; MINUSMA lorries came to assist and were set on fire by the jhadists.
The Malian army killed 7 jihadist fighters and injured 10 in fighting in the Tiebana forest, as the start of what officials said would be a three-month offensive. 
Gunmen stormed the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, opening fire and taking over 100 people hostage; 20 people died.
A UN convoy was hit with explosives on the road between Goundam and Timbuktu, killing 1 civilian staff member.
Ansar Dine claimed a rocket attack on the UN base in Kidal that killed 2 peacekeepers and a UN contractor.
Four gunmen shot out the tyres of a truck carrying migrants on the road to Kidal, and then killed 4 passengers and wounded 6.
AQIM gunmen attacked a military checkpoint in Nione; one Malian soldier was wounded and two were reported missing.
Islamists launched at least 4 shells at the UN barracks in Gao, but no casualties or damage was inflicted.
A gunman killed three people outside a Christian radio station in Timbuktu, including a radio presenter.
French forces engaged in fighting with AQIM in the Menaka region, killing or capturing 10 fighters and seizing vehicles and arms; the MAA claimed that 4 of its fighters had also been killed by the French in friendly fire, but a French source denied this.
Ansar Dine carried out two attacks in the Kidal region, killing at least 4 CMA fighters in one attack and 11 Tuareg fighters in another attack.

The presidential guard stages a coup, arresting Mauritania's first democratically elected president.  They are upset with corruption and his efforts at reaching out to hardliners.

Members of We are all Ely Ould Moktar held a sit-in protest in Nouakchott to demand the government secure the release of paramilitary officer Ely Ould Moktar from Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.
Students as well as various political and civilian groups participated in a protest outside Syria's embassy in Nouakchott. The demonstrators demanded Syrian diplomats be removed in light of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's abuse of democratic protesters.
Hundreds of members of the Islamic party Tewassoul demonstrated outside the Syrian embassy in Nouakchott in response to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's repressive treatment of protesters. The Tewassoul supporters demanded expulsion of Syrian diplomats.
The Coordination of a Democratic Oppostion, a coalition of opposition parties, held a lengthy series of weekly protests in Nouakchott demanding the resignation of President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz. Police arrested, beat, and tear gassed protesters on several occaisions. Some youth demonstrators resorted to throwing rocks and burning tires. Attendance ranged between hundreds and thousands.
Family members of sixteen moderate Dawa preachers gunned down by Mali troops protested outside President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz's palace in Nouakchott, demanding information about the deaths. The shooting occurred in Mali, but some of the victims were Mauritanian.

Thousands rioted in Zinder on January 16 and in Niamey on January 17 to protest Mohammed cartoons in Charlie Hebdo's post-attack "survivors' issue"; rioters burned 45 churches as well as French-owned and non-Muslim owned businesses; 10 were killed and at least 173 were injured.
Thousands rioted in Zinder on January 16 and in Niamey on January 17 to protest Mohammed cartoons in Charlie Hebdo's post-attack "survivors' issue"; rioters burned 45 churches as well as French-owned and non-Muslim owned businesses; 10 were killed and at least 173 were injured.
Around 300 people demonstrated in a long-planned protest against poor governance, despite the government's ban on demonstrations following two days of rioting; police used tear gas and arrested more than 90 people.
Boko Haram attacked the towns of Diffa and Bosso; Niger's defense minister reported 109 Islamists were killed, as well as four soldiers and a civilian.
Boko Haram attacked the towns of Diffa and Bosso; Niger's defense minister reported 109 Islamists were killed, as well as four soldiers and a civilian.
Boko Haram staged a series of attacks in the Diffa region, beginning with an overnight attack on February 7 and an explosion in a market later in the day that injured at least fifteen; on Feb 9, Boko Haram attempted to raid a prison and a car bomb exploded; on February 17, 3 Boko Haram members attackeda military post in nearby Bagara with knives.
Boko Haram staged a series of attacks in the Diffa region, beginning with an overnight attack on February 7 and an explosion in a market later in the day that injured at least fifteen; on Feb 9, Boko Haram attempted to raid a prison and a car bomb exploded; on February 17, 3 Boko Haram members attackeda military post in nearby Bagara with knives.
A suicide bomber was shot while attempting to blow himself up near a military post; no other casualties occurred.
An unidentified plane carried out an air strike on the Niger side of Abadam, a town that straddles the border with Nigeria, killing 20-30 people.
The government organized a protest against Boko Haram, during which President Mahamadou stated "Niger will be the death of Boko Haram."
Boko Haram attacked the village of Karouga, killing 14 militants and 7 Nigerien soldiers.
Boko Haram attacked villages on three islands in Lake Chad, killing at least 19 civilians.
Boko Haram attacked the town of Bosso and was repelled by troops from Niger and Chad, who reported that 47 Boko Haram fighters died, while government troops suffered no casualties.
Boko Haram attacked the island town and military base of Karamga, killing 46 soldiers and 28 civilians.
Moussa Tchangari and Nouhou Arzika were arrested on charges of violating national security after speaking out against the government; the organization Tchangari heads released a report criticizing the government's lack of response to humanitarian emergencies following Boko Haram attacks.
Thousands marched in Niamey to express numerous grievances against the government, including power cuts, tax increases, a projected increase in parliament members, and lack of freedoms.
Boko Haram attacked two villages in southeast Niger on June 17, killing at least 40; the military began air strikes against Boko Haram the following day, and reported 15 militants killed between June 18 and June 23.
Boko Haram attacked two villages in southeast Niger on June 17, killing at least 40; the military began air strikes against Boko Haram the following day, and reported 15 militants killed between June 18 and June 23.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Yebbi, killing five and burning more than 100 homes.
Boko Haram militants slit the throats of five civilians working at a construction site in Dagaya.
Boko Haram fighters raided a prison in Diffa in an attempt to free fellow members; one soldier and three militants were killed.
Boko Haram attacked a town near Bosso, killing 16 civilians; the army reported that it killed 32 Boko Haram fighters over the next three days in "sweeping up" operations undertaken in response.
Around a dozen Boko Haram militants attacked a village on the border with Nigeria, killing 15 civilians and burning 22 houses.
Boko Haram fighters ambushed Niger soldiers on their way to Baroua, leading to a firefight in which two soliders were killed.
Four suicide bombers from Boko Haram set off two explosions in Diffa, killing one policeman, five civilians, and the four bombers.
Hundreds of college and high school students protested in Niamey to demand more teachers and classes; after the police used tear gas, some demonstrators began throwing stones, burning tires, and burning cars; 79 were arrested.
Soldiers attacked would-be suicide bombers in Diffa, triggering their explosive devices and killing two soldiers as well as the bombers.
Boko Haram militants attacked the village of Ala, executing 13 and injuring 3.
Supporters of ex-president Ousmane demonstrated in Zinder to protest the ban on Ousmane participating in next year's election; police used tear gas on protesters and some participants threw stones and blocked traffic.
Five journalists were detained in Niamey, including one who published an article criticizing the deputy police chief and two who were covering the arrival and arrest of opposition candidate Hama Amadou; Reporters Without Borders condemned the arrests.
Police clashed with supporters of presidential candidate Hama Amadou outside the Niamey airport, where he was arrested on charges of baby trafficking upon his return to the country.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Wogom, killing 18 people and burning down around 100 homes.
Boko Haram attacked a village near Diffa, killing 4 and torching 50 homes.

2006 Central African Republic Government

Doctors strike to demand higher wages and the resumption of a national conference on democracy.  Nurses and other medical personnel join them in January 1992.
Supporters of an opposition politician burn the homes of Mobutu supporters and clash with troops.  Troops use tear gas and bullets to crush the demonstrators.  At least one person dies.
Mobutu fires the new prime minister.  When news breaks, thousands of anti-Mobutu activists take to the streets of Kinshasa and riot.  Several groups of anti-Mobutu protesters gather outside the French and Belgian embassies

Armed attackers invade the home of Monsignor Laurent Monsengwo Pasinya.
Zambia begins a crackdown on illegal Zairian immigrants.  Fearing that the same will happen to them, illegal Zambians in Zaire riot outside the Zambian embassy.
Port workers strike to demand democratic reforms.  The strikers dismantle part of the road connecting Matadi to Kinshasa, triggering a food crisis in the capital.
Sporadic protests occur outside the Bank of Zaire and the ministries of foreign affairs and justice as a result of a food shortage caused by an ongoing strike in Matadi.
A Christian church led march demands democratization and the re-opening of a democracy conference.  Soldiers open fire.  Deaths include a member of the elite Civil Guard.
Soldier led looting and violence in Kamina.
Soldiers rampage in eastern Zaire.  Thousands of refugees flee into Uganda.  At least 2 die when Ugandans cross the border to assist.
Thousands of people pour into the streets to protest in favor of democracy after Mobutu names Etienne Tshisekedi as prime minister.
Ethnic riots lead to 8 deaths.  The riots occur after Etienne Tshisekedi is elected prime minister over regional native Nguz Karl-i-Bond, who said after his defeat that the province would go into opposition.
Ethnic riots between Katangas and Kasais (Balubas).  Violence connected to the election of Etienne Tshisekedi, a Baluba, as prime minister over Katanga/Shaba native Nguzo Karl-i-Bond.
Protesters demonstrate against the issuance of five million Zaire banknote that the government has already demonetized.
Protesters riot, calling for the ouster of Mobutu.  Military forces fire into the crowd, killing 5.
Soldiers riot and loot in Goma to protest over back pay.
The Holy Alliance, a grouping of opposition parties, launches a general strike to protest the Mobutu dictatorship.
Riots and factional fighting.  Soldiers riot, loot, and clash with troops loyal to Mobutu.  They are angry that they are being paid in 5 million Zaire bank notes printed to keep up with hyperinflation.  Stray gunfire kills the French ambassador
Government soldiers fire a rocket into the home of an opposition leader's son, killing him.
Some 52 unarmed civilians are reportedly shot dead by Mobutu's elite guard.
Troops from Mobutu's special presidential guard back by tanks surround the National Assembly to demand that bank notes issued by Mobutu are accepted as legal currency.  They later surround the home of the interim prime minister.
Ethnic clashes.  Deaths are estimated.  Thousands die in ethnic clashes between Katangas and Balubas arising from Katangan support for an ousted prime minister and Baluba support for another.  A continuation of clashes in 1992.
Ethnic clashes over land and national rights.  Members of the Nyanga and Hunde tribes indigenous to Zaire attack Hutus and Tutsis from Rwanda.
Ethnic clashes over land and national rights.  Members of the Nyanga and Hunde tribes indigenous to Zaire attack Hutus and Tutsis from Rwanda.
Soldiers attack a rally for an opposition political party.  4 are killed.
Hundreds of soldiers riot and loot.  Further details unknown.
Soldiers explode a grenade in an open air market, killing 3.
Rebels fighting to overthrow the government stage an attack.
Rwandan refugees stampede as they flee from Tutsi rebels into Zaire.  Up to 50 die.
Two soldiers are killed by outraged refugees frustrated by robbery.
A Zairian paratrooper kills a moneychanger, triggering riots in protest.
Riots occur in refugee camps over food delivery and thefts by machete wielding gangs.

Ethnic violence, thuggery, and terror attacks occur throughout Goma and several Rwandan refugee camps.  Gangs attack each other, and roving bands of Zairian soldiers rob refugees.

Hutu refugees attack each other, alleging collusion with the Rwandan Patriotic Front.  Several incidents occur.

Zairian soldiers try to steal a Rwandan owned car.  Infuriated refugees clash with the soldiers, who call in reinforcements that fire on the crowd.  The next day, a crowd of refugees assaults a Reuters TV crew.
Rwandan refugees steal 50 Zairian cows and flee across the border.  Cattle owners and butchers seek the help of thugs and for several hours stage riots in Goma and blockade the Mugunga refugee camp.
A group of 6 Hutu militants accuse a fellow ethnic of being a spy for the Tutsis and invade an aid agency to kill him.
An unknown assailant sets off a grenade, killing 5 refugees.  The refugees then riot.
Violent demonstrations and riots in Goma over robberies by Zairian soldiers.  Civilian mobs carjack aid workers.  The violence causes Japan to withdraw its peacekeepers in the area.
Factional violence erupts in a refugee camp.  Hundreds of bandits believed to be Hutu militias take over the camp, forcing aid workers to flee.
Militant and mob violence in the refugee camps leads to 6 deaths.  Three foreign doctors are also killed.
Native Zairians and Hutus clash over ethnic issues and cattle.
Rioting refugees clash with Zairian troops, triggering a battle in which 15 die.  During the violence, a British member of Action-Aid is kidnapped.
A strike called by opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi turns Kinshasa into a ghost town.
Civil servants strike over back wages.
Refugees stone aid workers to protest a reduction in food rations.
Tutsi militias from Rwanda retaliate for cross-border raids by Hutus.  They cross Lake Kivu from Rwanda and attack refugees on Iwinja island.  They then go ashore on the Zairian side of the lake and attack a refugee camp.
Unknown attackers ambush an aid convoy.
Disputes over land, cattle, and ethnic issues cause a clash between native Zairians and Banayrwanda, ethnic groups from Rwanda.  Banayrwanda stage a massacre of native Zairians.
Disputes over land, cattle, and ethnic issues cause a clash between native Zairians and Banayrwanda, ethnic groups from Rwanda.  Banayrwanda stage a massacre of native Zairians.
A series of protests erupts after the interim parliament announces that the first general elections in a decade would be postponed for another two years.
12 people die in a opposition group demonstration.
Men in military uniform rob and kill 4 Italian aid workers with Mondo Giusto plus two children.
A bomb targeting the chief of the Zairian army explodes prematurely onboard a plane.  No one is hurt.
Unknown attack over unknown reasons in a largely unknown location.
Factional violence erupts near refugee camps.  Local Hunde tribesmen attack Hutus, Hutus attack Tutsis, and Zairian soldiers fight everyone, looting and robbing as they go.
A lieutenant colonel in a special army unit dies when he tries to disarm a drunken soldier with a grenade.  The deaths trigger rioting between two army units that leave at least 50 dead, mostly civilians.
Hutu rebels attack Rwandan soldiers in a national park.
Armed Hutus with rifles and machetes hunt down hundreds of Tutsis who had hidden in a Zairian church, killing at least 12.
Unknown gunmen ambush a military convoy, killing 7.
Angry Zairian soldiers blockade the airport to demand that troops wounded by unknown gunmen be transferred by plane to Kinshasa.
Hostile elements cross the border from Uganda, killing 30 villagers.
Unknown gunmen attack a Red Cross warehouse.
Tens of thousands of people march to protest in favor of democratization.
Zairian soldiers clash with Banyamulenge.  Deaths and numbers are unknown.
Marauders attack a Swedish missionary hospital and a Catholic missionary station, killing 40 people and committing many atrocities.  The attackers are believed to be Tutsis angry that the hospitals were treating Hutus.
Unknown attackers kill three civilians.
Armed men raid Bambu, killing between 50 and 60 civilians.  The violence is ethnic in nature, although the factions are not reported.
Tutsi militia attack Hutu refugees.
1996 Democratic Republic of the Congo Government
Students protest and riot, demanding that the prime minister step down.  They also protest outside the Burundi embassy to protest against the Tutsi-controlled government there.
More than 10,000 students storm through the capital in stolen vehicles to demand the resignation of the prime minister.  They condemn and attack foreign journalists, accusing them of being Rwandans.  Government forces shoot dead three students.
Carrying the coffin of a slain student over their heads, rioting students storm Parliament to demand the resignation of the prime minister, accused of allowing rebels to take over eastern Zaire.  Protests continue the next day.
Students call for a mass business boycott to rally against the government.  Shop owners and public transport workers strike.  Students line the road to the airport, blocking passage.  Soldiers use tear gas when rioters throw rocks at an EU dele
About 5000 protesters take to the streets demanding that Etienne Tshisekedi be returned to the prime minister's office.  Police use clubs.
Unknown men attack Bukavu.
Dozens of journalists employed by state run TV and radio surround the French embassy to demand that France not pursue charges against Zaire's ambassador to that country.
Protesters gather outside the home of Etienne Tshisekedi, the main opposition leader, to demand that Mobutu resign.  They also cheer for the rebel leader Laurent Kabila.
Protesters gather to demand that Mobutu resign.  Government forces arrest and beat the leader of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress.
About 200 protesters demonstrate outside the US embassy, blaming it for the civil war.
Pro-Tshisekedi supporters riot outside of parliament as it discusses ousting him as prime minister.  Police break up the riot with tear gas and clubs.
Thousands of protesters try to push past a line of police to carry Etienne Tshisekedi into the prime minister's office.
General strike called in opposition to Mobutu in Kinshasa and the five provinces that remain under government control.  Several marches and protests occur, and soldiers fire on them, but no one is hurt.
Rwandan refugees kill seven villagers.
Local Zairians hurl stones at UN vehicles and loot a WFP depot to protest the killing of Zairian villagers by Rwandan refugees.
Several hundred students and supporters of an opposition political party demonstrate against Laurent Kabila in the first such protest in the capital.
Hotel staff strike because rebels have not paid their bills in a rebel controlled city.
A citywide general strike is called by the opposition to protest against the issuance of a 100,000 Zaire bank note and to demand that Mobutu resign.
The immigration service strikes over back pay, stopping traffic on the river between Kinshasa and Brazzaville.
Violence erupts after the government falls and rebels enter the capital.  Widespread looting.  Civilians take revenge on former regime soldiers.  Most of the dead are civilians caught in the cross-fire.
Troops from the rebel army (now considered to be the government actor after the fall of Mobutu) shoot and kill a Hutu student.
Professors fearing pay cuts strike after the new government reduced tuition at the University of Lumumbashi.
Hutu protesters demonstrate against the killing of a student the day before.
Various religious and professional groups demonstrate with more the 10,000 people in support of the self-proclaimed president, Laurent Kabila.
Anti-government protest.  Kabila's troops disperse the demonstration.
Anti-government protest after 10 people are killed during a night of violence and kidnappings.  Kabila's troops fire on the demonstrators, killing dozens.
About 2000 people protest against the new president, Laurent Kabila.  Government (ex-rebel) troops beat the protesters.
Unknown men attack a group of Rwandan children and a civilian aid worker.
Several hundred protesters march against the new government.
Anti-government protest.  Kabila's troops disperse the demonstration.
Opposition parties protest against the new government, demanding that unbanning of political activity.  The police use tear gas and violently beat several people.  Seven people are clubbed to death.
Students demonstrate against the death of a fellow student shot dead by the military.
Anti-government protest.  50 youth wing members of an opposition political party are subsequently arrested and tortured.
Thousands of Laurent Kabila's supporters protest Western demands for an investigation into the massacre of refugees during the war by the rebels now controlling the government.
50 soldiers riot to protest the government's failure to pay their wages.
A gun battle occurs between rival groups of soldiers loyal to Laurent Kabila.
Former Zairean army soldiers attack Bukavu.
Rebels attack a Ugandan refugee camp.
Demonstration in front of the French embassy to protest again France's position toward DRC and its alleged involvement with the rebels.
Mai Mai and Hutus attack the Tutsi rebels controlling Goma.
Women protest in rebel-held Goma, demanding that the government negotiate with the rebels.
Mai Mai attack rebels controlling Bukavu.
Ethnic war between Hema and Lendu leads to 5000 deaths.  Ugandan troops are accused of siding with the Hema.
Ethnic groups battle over land rights.  370 killed when Wahema pastoralists are killed by Balendu farmers.
Street protests erupt when Catholic Archbishop Emmanuel Kataliko is expelled from the city by the rebels.
Inhabitants stage a series of protests over the fact that Rwandan soldiers are present in Bukavu supporting rebels.
A general strike in rebel-held Goma over unknown causes.
Hutu militias kill dozens in and around Goma throughout July.
A gunfight erupts around the house of opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi.
News of the death of Catholic Archbishop Emmanuel Kataliko sparks riots in Bukavu.
A demonstration occurs outside the home of a local government official named president of the Rwandan backed wing of the Congolese Rally for Democracy.  Rwandan soldiers backing the rebels open fire on the demonstrators, killing 20.
Lendu armed with spears and guns attack a Hema village, killing an unknown number and creating some 5000 refugees who flee into Uganda.
President Laurent Kabila is shot dead by a bodyguard in the presence of generals he angered by sacking.
The military abducts and kills 11 Lebanese migrant workers because they are suspected of being involved in Kabila's assassination.
Lendu and Ngiti attack Bunia to destroy a Ugandan helicopter that has been used against them.  The Ugandans drive back the attack, and then the Lendu and Ngiti militia attack Hema families, killing at least 50.
Tens of thousands of people march in favor of new president Joseph Kabila.
Gunmen ambush and kill 6 Red Cross workers.  The gunmen are later accused of belonging to the Ugandan army.
Rival fans invade a soccer match, triggering a riot and a stampede.

Ngiti tribesmen ambush Ugandan soldiers they believe murdered a member of the tribe.
Civil servants strike to protest the rebels' decision to requisition money earned by utilities and other state organizations.
Ethnic clashes between Lendu and Hemas begins a process of ethnic mobilization that will result in open war between the two in May.
Mai Mai and rebels clash.
Lendu raiders attack Hema civilians, resulting in 100 deaths, including Ugandan soldiers.

Rwandan back RCD rebels take Moliro in violation of a ceasefire.

Fighting between the government forces allied with Hutu rebels and those of the rebel RCD.
Students protest for peace in rebel held Bukavu.  Rebel military forces disperse the protesters with some instances of brutality.

Ethnic war driven by disputes over land claim 1400 lives.

A tense stand-off/protest ensues between ANC and Inkatha Freedom Party supporters ahead of an ANC rally.  The situation nearly turns into a riot, but police keep them apart with tear gas.
Police and civil servants strike in the Ciskei region because they fear losing their pay and benefits once Apartheid ends and the region is dissolved.  They take fellow officers and wives hostage.  The strike leads to rioting and looting.

A bombing spree perpetrated by whites.  On 4/24, a car bomb kills 9 people in Johannesburg near the ANC headquarters.  On 4/25, a bomb destroys a taxi stand used by black commuters in Pretoria.  Another bomb explodes the same day in Gerimston.

Teachers went on strike to demand 4.5% salary increase, defying court ruling. Initially reported as teacher's strike, later involved broader set of public service workers. Nurses abandoned strike in favor of work slowdown on July 24. Over 300 teachers ignoring court order to end strike fired on Aug. 2. Teachers abandoned strike around Aug. 15.

Thousands of people gathered along the road from the airport to Antananarivo to greet returning former leader Marc Ravalomanana.  His flight was turned back to South African, and one supporter was killed in internal scuffles within the crowd. Police used tear gas to dispearse between 3,000 and 5,000 unauthorized Protesters who had gathered in support of opposition radio station, radio Free FM.
The police and army successfully put down a mutiny attempt lead by Koto Mainty, who was killed during the fighting.  The mutiny was staged out of the Ivatu military base near Antananarivo after renegade soldiers killed the officer sent to negotiatie with them.  Soldiers who participated in the mutiny were reportedly paid to do so.
Following an attempted mutiny, soldiers cut power to opposition radio Free FM, keeping it off the air for over 7 hours.  The military then gathered outside the station, causing its staff to take their equiptment and flee.  Soldiers late seized a computer screen and a voltage regulator.
A bomb was placed under the car of an army officer while it was parked outside a nightclub.  The explosion injured three people, none fatally.
Villagers ambushed cattle thieves, killing 67 in one attack and 23 in a subsequent ambush.  Several clashes afterwards left both police and thieves dead.  Authorities established security areas to avoid reprisal attacks by the thieves.
Over several months, students and staff engaged in sometimes violent protests at Antananarivo University to protest unpaid grants and salaries.  After one final bout of unrest, authorities announced that students would receive one month's scholarship with an equipment grant, while staff would get their unpaid salaries.

Supporters of the February 20 reform movement protested in Al Hoceima, Beni Bouayache, and Imzouren after police arrested Bachir Benchaib, one of the movements local leaders. Police used nonlethal methods such as water cannons to disperse crowds, but were eventually attacked by protesters who were also demanding more electricity and water for their villages.

Three hundred members of Morocco's Democratic League for Women's Rights held a sit-in demonstration outside the local court in Larache to protest the court's decision to allow a rapist to marry his victim. The young girl who was raped committed suicide, drawing attention to the law that allowed the marriage.
About two hundred women associated with the Democratic Association of the Women of Morocco protested outside the parliament building in Rabat. The group was angered by a law that allowed rapists to escape punishment by marrying their victim and had subsequently produced a young girl's suicide.
Hundreds of unemployed Moroccans protested outside the parliament as the government worked to pass its yearly budget. Police clashed with the protesters and forcibly removed some.

Arab Spring.  Riots occur over rising food prices and chronic unemployment.  Police respond with deadly violence.  A wave of dozens of self-immolations sweeps the country.  3 die during the riots, 4 die in the immolations.

Unknown assailants trade gunfire with police in front of the main opposition party's headquarters, and around the presidential palace.
Demonstrators demand the abolition of the ruling RCD party; they are repelled by police with tear gas
Riot police break up a protest led by a banned Islamist movement.
Teachers strike to demand that members of the ruling party stay out of power.
For the first time, a pro-government protest occurs during the Tunisian Revolution.  Clashes and riots occur.
The main trade union organizes a strike and a rally of 50,000 people, calling for the government to resign.
Police clash with demonstrators who set fire to a local police headquarters.
Tunis airport ground staff strike.
Police strike to be allowed to set up a union.
Police strike to be allowed to set up a union.
Police strike to be allowed to set up a union.
An unemployed Tunisian self-immolates to protest 'deplorable social conditions.'
Protests resume nationwide.  Some escalate to riots.
Hundreds demonstrate in favor of a secular state.
Thousands protest at the governmental palace to demand the ouster of the provisional government.
Over 100 activists protest in front of the Libya embassy over the repression used against the uprising there.
Protests escalate to riots between stone-throwing protesters and police.
Clashes erupt between residents of a town over jobs.  The clashes begin after a false employment offer allegedly posted by a phosphate mining company imposes tribal based employment quotas.
Hundreds of Islamists protest the country' secular laws.  Police use tear gas.
Hundreds of former ruling party members protest a new measure forbidding former party officials from running in elections.
Police break up a demonstration against the provision government with tear gas.
Al Qaeda militants fight with security forces.
Residents of a town clash with refugees from Libya.  The refugees protest because they believe they are going to sent back to their home countries (refugees are mainly foreign workers contracted to work in Libya).  Four Eritreans are killed.
Lorry drivers strike to demand better working conditions and to protest abusive layoffs.
Tribal factions clash after rumors surface about the recruitment policies of the region's main employer, a phosphate mining company.
Judges strike, demanding changes in the justice ministry, which they accuse of threatening them.
Riots occur in the birthplace of the Arab Spring.  Police open fire on rioters, killing a 14 year old boy.
Lawyers riot to protest corruption in the courts and too-lax verdicts against those connected to the old regime.
Clashes occur in the town of Douz.  The cause is unknown.
Teenage youths riot, looting shops.  Police open fire, killing one teenager.  In retaliation, residents of Sbeitla burn down the police station.
Fighting between rival clans over access to jobs.
Five people try to hang themselves after failing a competition to become teachers.  They are rescued by a crowd of bystanders.  The suicide attempt is followed by a sit-in.
Teenage youths clash with police.
200 Salafists storm a university campus after a female student wearing a full face-veil is not allowed to sign up.
Salafists attack the offices of a private TV station that aired Persepolis, a French-Iranian animation film in which God is portrayed as an old bearded man.
Salafists protest in front of a TV station that they accuse of blasphemy for airing a film with an image of God.  Police use tear gas.  Several hours later, about a hundred men fire bomb the TV station.  Thousands of marchers then gather to denounce the station.
Women protest to protect their rights after the election victory of an Islamist party.
Thousands protest over the exclusion of local residents from a list of those killed in the 2010 uprising.  Demonstrators set fire to a prison, rob a bank, and loot a government agency. Police use tear gas.
A sit-in by ultraconservative Muslims, who are not university students, demanding students be allowed to attend classes in the conservatve face veil
Border guards stop work, complaining of a lack of protection against armed fighters on the Libyan side of the border.
Liberal demonstrators rally in front of parliament to protest against extremism during the drafting of a new constitution.  Thousands of Islamists descend on the liberals, prompting a riot.  Police use tear gas.

A protest and general strike against the lack of progress since Ben Ali fled. Locals say there are no jobs, no running water, no gas, and corrupt officials and investors.

Libyans protest at UN building and British embassy demanding the release of man convicted in Lockerbie trial.

Families of a group of children infected with the HIV by Bulgarian medics protest the arrival of Bulgaria's foreign minister.

Qadhafi supporters gather to celebrate the 36th anniversary of the coup that put Qadhafi in power.
Protests against Pres. Bush's demand for the release of 5 nurses and 1 doctor accused of infecting children with the HIV virus.
Families of children infected with the HIV virus protest outside court proceedings involving those accused, protest turned violent when the judge announced a postponement of the trial.

Muslims violently protest Italian Minister Calderoli's decision to wear at t-shrit with caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad.

Libyans protest alleged mistreatment of Kadhafi's son during his arrest in Switzerland.
2011 Libyan uprising.  Spontaneous uprising over food prices, jobs, and democracy.
Libyan Civil War.  Rebels advance from Benghazi to overthrow Qaddafi
1500 protesters call for the end of Gadhafi's regime.
Over 10,000 protesters pour into the streets, demanding that Kadhafi surrender power.
Protests are reported in the capital as NATO airstrikes continue.
Two days of anti-regime protests are reported.
Rival rebel factions clash.
Large anti-Khadafi protests are reported on the day that the rebels enter Tripoli.
Clash between rebel militias.
Hundreds of Berbers march to pressure the government for representation.
Rebel factions clash after Rojban fighters from the west demand the release of a comrade held in a security services building.
Dozens of protesters demand that militia fighters pull out of the capital.
Hundreds of residents and police protest against rebel militias camped out in the capital.
Gunmen try to assassinate the head of Libya's new army, triggering hours of gun battles.
5000 demonstrators protest to demand that the head of the NTC resign, complaining of a lack of transparency and willingness to forgive Khadafi fighters.  The protests are countered by NTC rallies.
People in Khadafi's home town protest against the town's marginalization in the 'New Libya.'
As many as four thousand students of the University of Ghar Yunis and former rebels gathered in Benghazi to protest the transitional government's lack of transparency. Protests led to the resignation of the National Transitional Council deputy. The NTC headquarters were also attacked by protesters.
Mistrata militiamen attacked members of the Al-Zawiyah militia in Tripoli, resulting in the death of four militants and the wounding of some five others. The Mistrata militants were allegedly attempting to rescue a comrade detained by the Al-Zawiyah militia.
Responding to the stabbing of a fellow townsmen, The Martyrs Brigade of Gharyan  entered Asbi'a and were  confronted by the Asbi'a's militia . The ensuing conflict lasted three days and claimed the lives of four. An estimated fifty individuals were injured.
Ten Libyan youths protested in the lobby of a Tripoli hotel where Egyptian ruler Hussein Tantawin was speaking. The demonstraters demanded the return of former Khadafi loyalists in Egypt and expressed support for fellow revolutionaries in Egypt.
Over one hundred armed Khadafi loyalists known as Brigade 93 attacked Bani Walid. Four were killed and many more injured.
As members of the Syrian National Council took control of the Syrian embassy in Tripoli, dozens of suppoters gathered outside to protest the rule of Bashar al-Assad. The following day, roughly two hundred Syrians broke into the Russian embassy and raised the Syrian rebel flag to protest Russia's UN vetoes.
After a small initial conflict, extened violence broke out between the Zwai and Tobu. Heavy weapson were used and over one hunder people were killed, including numerous civilians
In an effort to discourage a pro-Khadafi resurgence, Libya unitied militia forces held a military parade through Tripoli.
Thousands of Libyan gathered in Benghazi's Tahrir Square to celebrate the anniversary of the revolt that overthrew Khadafi.
Members of the Saraya Swehli militia kidnapped two British journalists and their three Libyan companions.
Angry Salafist protesters desecrated WWII graves in Benghazi in response to U.S. troops in Afghanistan burning the Koran.
Thousands protested in Benghazi and Tripoli at the prospect of a federal system of governance. One individual was killed as protesters set fire to a Benghazi market.
Thousands protested in Benghazi and Tripoli at the prospect of a federal system of governance. One individual was killed as protesters set fire to a Benghazi market.
Following a speech by pro-federalist leader Ahmed Zubeir Senussi, two thousand federalist supporters clashed with anti-federalists. One individual was killed in the conflict and five others were injured.
Arab tribesmen clashed with Tabu  in Sabha. The ethnically fueled conflict produced around one hundred and sixty-three deaths and wounded hundreds others.
Around thirty former rebels belonging to the Katibat al-Awfiya militia held a sit-in protest at Benghazi's airport. The demonstrators demanded government compensation for their servince in the revolt.
The militia Ragdalein captured men from Zwara because of alleged looting and abuses during the previous year's revolt. Zwara's forces attacked in response and seventeen individuals were killed and dozens others wounded.
The militia Ragdalein captured men from Zwara because of alleged looting and abuses during the previous year's revolt. Zwara's forces attacked in response and seventeen individuals were killed and dozens others wounded.
Five Tunisians were captured in the Tunisian-Libyan and held hostage for two days.
Former rebels held small demonstrations in front of the interim government building in Tripoli and constructed several blockades throughout the city. The militiamen were angered by the government's decision to suspend compensation to rebels. The government's headquarters were fired upon, but no injuries were reported.
A convoy of UN officials travelling in Benghazi was attacked with a hand grenade. No injuries occurred and the assailant remained unidentified.
Armed Libyans detained Tunisian workers and demanded freedom for a small group of Libyans held in Tunisia.
Elements of the national army attacked members of the Tobu in Kufra. The conflict produced twelve deaths and many more deaths.
Prisoners in Benghazi made a violent attempt at escape, but were stopped by guards. Three guards and three prisoners were killed.
Unknown individuals damaged a courthouse in Benghazi using explosive devices. The attack wounded three individuals.
A demonstration of dozens of former rebels ended peacefully when leader of the National Transitional Council Abdel Jalil came out of the NTC headquarters and placated the crowd.
Police killed two militiamen in Tripoli after the former revolutionaries refused to cede control of territory in the capital.
Militiamen, some from Yefran, surrounded the government headquarters in Tripoli and protested the government's refusal to compensate former rebels as well as its failure provide medical care to the wounded. The protesters then turned violent and one individual was killed and four injured in the subsequent fray.
A group of armed individuals killed Khaled Abu Saleh outside of Ubari. Saleh had just registered in an upcoming General National Congress election.
A group of Tuareg tribesmen attacked the town of Ghadames in response to their expulsion from Ghadames and several other communities. Six Tuaregs and one citizen of Ghadames were killed during the attack.
Assailants hit the International Committiee of the Red Cross's office in Benghazi with an RPG. No casualties occurred.
Unknown individuals struck the Benghazi branch of Sahara Bank with a rocket, causing some damage, but no injuries.
Tarhouna militiamen forcefully seized Tripoli's airport in response to their leader's arrest. Government forces retook the airport several hours later.
Assailants struck the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi with a bomb. Minimal damage was incurred and no one was wounded.
Dozens of activists, including women, held a protest in Benghazi to criticize other demonstrators for bringing weapons to a rally in support of Sharia law. The activists successfully dispered the Sharia rally.
Over three hundred heavily armed men protested in Benghazi's Tahrir Square just before Libya's assembly election. The demonstrators demanded Libya be ruled under Sharia law.
Members of the Tobu minority attacked a government checkpoint. The Libya Shield Brigade, an element of the national army, retaliated with an assault on Kufra. Twenty Tobu and three soldiers were killed.
Unknown assailants attacked a British diplomatic convoy in Benghazi with a RPG. Two British bodyguards were injured in the attack.
Zintan rebels attacked members of the el-Manshisha, a rival tribe that did not participate in the anti-Gadhafi uprising. The attack was a response to the shooting of a Zintan rebel by alleged el-Manshisha members. Twelve individuals were killed and eighty-nine wounded in the retaliation.
Zintan rebels attacked members of the el-Manshisha, a rival tribe that did not participate in the anti-Gadhafi uprising. The attack was a response to the shooting of a Zintan rebel by alleged el-Manshisha members. Twelve individuals were killed and eighty-nine wounded in the retaliation.

The International Commission of the Red Cross's Misrata office was hit by an explosive device that injured one individual. The source and purpose of the attack were unknown.
In a recurring conflict, fighting broke out between members of the Tobu and Zwai tribes in Kufra. Government militia forces were attacked when they attempted to intervene. One individual was killed and several injured.
In response to widespread violence and insecurity, dozens of Libyans protested in Benghazi. The demonstrators requested  the government control the militias and reinstate order.
Assailants fired on a security patrol traveling in Sabha, killing two and wounding ten.
Unidentified individuals destroyed the headstones of WWII Allied soldiers in Benghazi. The graves were believed to be targeted for religious reasons.
Armed members of the Partisans of Shariah seized the Tunisian consulate in Benghazi, but eventually withdrew peacefully.
In Derna, unknown individuals killed former Khadafi officers and other individuals in a series of killings that extended over months.
In Kufra, Tobu tribesmen clashed with members of the Zwai tribe. The Libya Shield Brigade attempted to stop the fighting, but was drawn into the conflict. Around thrity-two individuals, including women and children, were killed and many more wounded.
Rioters under the nominal leadership of Abdeljawad al-Badin attacked the offices of the electoral commission in Benghazi ahead of national assembly elections. The perpetrators were angered by the government's dismissal of their demands for a federal system.
Abdel-Hakim Belhaj, leader of the Al-Watan party, spoke to hundreds about the need for Sharia in Libya's emerging democracy. The rally in Tripoli occurred a week before national elections.
Supporters of federalism attempted to attack a warehouse containing national election ballots but were peacefully stopped by residents of Ajdabiya. The following day, the ballots were burnt.
The Alliance for National Forces led a parade of cars through Tripoli to advocate their party in the upcoming election.
Members of the Justice and Construction Party held a march through Tripoli in anticipation of upcoming elections.
Wadi Ahmar shut down oil facilities in Al-Sedra, Haruj, Zuwaytina, Brega and Al-Hariga. The group's efforts were an attempt to make the government divide legislative seats on the basis of region and not demographics.

Unidentified attackers fired on a helicopter transporting election officials, killing one. The incident occurred near the edge of Benghazi.
Unknown individuals fired two rockets at the Benghazi Medical Centre, failing to cause any casualities or damage.
Unidentified gunmen attacked polling stations in several locations throughout Libya. In Ajdabiya, one individual was killed and two injured.

In Benghazi, hundreds of protesters burned ballots and asked the government to provide greater democracy.
Hundreds of Libyans gathered in Tripoli and Benghazi to celebrate the country's first post-Gadhafi election. In Benghazi, military members participated in the demonstration, but once they left protester became violent and destroyed property.

Two Misrata journalists were captured in Bani Walid, a community known for its former allegiance to Khadafi.
Khadafi loyalists kidnapped Omran Ben Shaaban, the man responsible for Khadafi's capture, and three of his associates. Shaaban was shot while trying to escape. Later released, he died of the injuries received during his captivity.
One person was wounded in Tripoli during a fight over market space. The conflict featured gunfire and a car bomb.
Unknown individuals attacked the residence of Red Cross workers in Misrata with heavy weaponry.
In Al-Aziziya, a unit of the interior ministry brigade raided the hideout of individuals tied to several bomb plots. Three suspects were killed and five security officers wounded.
Derna's city security chief was killed by unknown individuals.
Khadafi loyalists detonated two bombs in Tripoli, targeting a military academy and an office of the interior ministry. Two individuals were killed and four injured in the attacks.
Security forces attacked Katibat al-Awfiya, a pro-Khadafi militia, near Tarhuna. One individual was killed, eight injured, and thirteen arrested. Additionally, over one hundred tanks and other heavy weaponry were seized.
Two rival tribes in Zliten attacked each other with light and heavy weaponry in an attempt to settle a long-standing dispute. Two individuals were killed.
Islamic fundamentalists destroyed Sufi shrines in Tripoli, Misrata, and Zliten because they viewed the idea of worhipping tombs as sacrilegious.

Dozens of Libyans protested in Tripoli in response to the government's inability to deal with religious violence.
Islamic radicals, long abused under Khadafi, planted and detonated a bomb in the car of colonel of the former regime. The colonel was killed and his assistant wounded.
Muslim fundamentalists attempted  to destroy a shrine in Rajma, but were stopped by local militia and national security forces. Three individuals were killed and many others wounded.
Islamic terrorists laid seige to the United States consulate in Benghazi, killing U.S. Ambassador Christopher Stevens and three other diplomats. Several others were wounded. The attack was conducted by around fifty militants armed with grenades and guns.
Members of Ansar al-Sharia beat and stabbed Catholic nuns and  a priest in Derna.
Hundreds of protesters gathered in Tripoli and Benghazi to condem the terrorist attack against the U.S. consolate in Benghazi days earlier.

Derna residents held a lengthy sit-in protest outside the Sahaba Mosque and called for the disbanding of Ansar al-Sharia, a militant group responsible for recent violence.
About two hundred individuals belonging to the Ansar al-Shariah militia marched through Benghazi to express their faith in Muhammad and anger over an anti-Muslim film.
Air traffic controllers at Libya's international airports in Tripoli and Benghazi went on strike to demand better salaries and equipment.

Khadafi loyalists entered into an extended conflict with pro-government militia in Barek al-Shati. Ninteen individuals were killed and thirty militiamen were captured.
 march organized by Mohammed Abujanah and others to protest the continued presence of militias. Activists attempted to violently oust Ansar al-Sharia and other Islamist militias from their bases. Eleven individuals, including security forces, were killed and about seventy injured. The city residents were particularly angered by Ansar al-Sharia's religious fanatacism and possible link to Ambassador Chris Steven's death.
In Benghazi, hundreds of members of Ansar al-Sharia protested the creation of anti-Muslim film by an amatuer U.S. film producer and an offensive French cartoon. The protesters also criticized U.S. President Barack Obama while praising God.
The national army forcefully removed militias in Tripoli still lingering from anti-Khadafi uprising.
Over two hundred Salafist protesters demanded the return of extremist militia Ansar al-Sharia to Benghazi. The protesters grew violent and attacked security forces with grenades and burned cars.
Around two hundred protesters marched in Tripoli, asking the government to disband militias and create a more centralized security force.
Khadafi loyalists from Bani Walid clashed with militiamen from Misrata in the valley of Mardun, just outside of the loyalists' town. Three militiamen were wounded.
Muslim extremists attacked four policeman at a checkpoint in Susa. Three of the officers were killed and the last was left in critical condition.
Over one hundred demonstrators from Zawiyah barged into the national assembly to complain that no one from their city had been selected for the PM's cabinet.
Around one thousand demonstrators gathered outside the national assembly building in Tripoli, requesting the government peacefully end the military seige of Bani Walid.
The Libyan Shield and militia from Misrata laid seige to Bani Walid, believed to be one of the last strongholds of Khadafi loyalists. Thirty individuals were killed and over two hundred were wounded.
In Benghazi, demonstrators looted a private television station after it reported unsubstantiated claims that the government had captured key Khadafi figures.
Armed men attacked the barracks of defense ministry forces in Tripoli. No casualties were reported.
Around two hundred demonstrators gathered outside the national assembly building in Tripoli to protest the seige of Bani Walid. Security forces physically restrained and beat protesters. The demonstration was finally dispersed when government forces fired warning shots into the air.
Hundreds of Libyans gathered in Tripoli and Benghazi to celebrate one year since the country's liberation from the Khadafi regime.

Farj Libya planes carried out a strike on the Zintan airport, where the militia is allied with the recognized government.
Air forces from the elected government carried out strikes on Fajr Libya warehouses and positions in Zuara.
IS and Fajr Libya forces clashed over several days in Sirte and areas nearby; Fajr Libya reported that 5 soldiers were killed on March 14 and 15 in Sirte, and 12 soldiers were killed on March 18.
IS and Fajr Libya forces clashed over several days in Sirte and areas nearby; Fajr Libya reported that 5 soldiers were killed on March 14 and 15 in Sirte, and 12 soldiers were killed on March 18.

A car bomb exploded at the base of the 166th Battalion, a milita aligned with Tripoli that had been battling IS; one person was killed and one was injured.
IS militants kidnapped four Filipino nurses from the Ibn Sina hospital in Sirte.
IS fighters attacked a checkpoint near Nofaliyah that was manned by militia aligned with the Tripoli-based government; 12 militiamen were killed.
Air and ground troops allied with the Tobruk government attacked sites in and around Tripoli over several days; fighting also occurred in Aziziya and Zawiya, and air strikes were carried out against multiple targets, including the Matiga airport.

The Tobruk government carried out an airstrike against an arms depot belonging to Islamist militants in the town of Tarhouna, allegedly killing 8 Tawergha refugees; in response, the militants killed 4 civilians.
A plane aligned with the Tripoli government bombed Zintan, a town that supports the Tobruk government; soldiers from the Tobruk government shot it down.
Three suicide bombings took place at military checkpoints in Benghazi, killing 12 people and wounding 25; IS claimed responsibility for one, and the Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries claimed two.
IS fighters attacked a checkpoint of militia aligned with Farj Libya in Sirte, killing 5 militiamen.
A rocket attack in Zawiya killed a Filipino oil worker and wounded five other civilians.
IS fighters attacked a checkpoint outside of Misrata, killing 7 fighters from the Libya Shield Force, which is part of the Fajr Libya alliance.
An IS suicide bomber blew up a vehicle at the Saddada checkpoint east of Misrata, killing 6 people (mostly militiamen) and injuring 21.
10 soldiers were killed and 40 were wounded when government forces clashed with armed groups in Benghazi.
Loyalist fighters and Fajr militia fought for two days in Aziziya.
Gunmen opened fire on the South Korean embassy compound from a passing car, killing two guards and wounding a third person; hours later, a bomb exploded outside the Moroccan embassy but caused no casualties. IS  claimed responsibility for both attacks.
Airstrikes were carried out against the Tripoli airport.
A tugboat belonging to Libyan security forces detained an Italian trawler about 90km northwest of Misrata; the trawler was then boarded by the Italian navy, which recaptured it and took control.
Loyalist forces attacked Tajoura and Tripoli in an attempt to wrest control from Fajr Libya; it was reported that 3 civilians were killed in Tripoli, and that 14 soldiers, 4 Fajr Libya fighters, and 3 civilians were killed in Tajoura.
Loyalist forces attacked Tajoura and Tripoli in an attempt to wrest control from Fajr Libya; it was reported that 3 civilians were killed in Tripoli, and that 14 soldiers, 4 Fajr Libya fighters, and 3 civilians were killed in Tajoura.
IS released a video of Libyan jihadists killing 30 Ethiopian Christians who had been kidnapped; the victims consisted of two groups filmed in two separate locations.
A bomb exploded outside the Spnish embassy in Tripoli, damaging the building and others nearby but causing no casualties; IS claimed responsibility.
Fajr Libya and IS forces clashed in a fight to control Sirte, and Fajr Libya carried out air strikes on IS in Sirte the next day.
protesters in eastern Libya shut oil deliveries to a port.
The Libyan air force attacked a Turkish cargo vessel after it was asked several times to turn back from the coast and did not; a sailor was killed.
Shelling in several residential neighborhoods in Benghazi killed at least 27 people in the course of several days, including 10 children; no actor was identified, but a source suspected some shelling was due to the killing of an IS fighter earlier in the week.
IS fighters attacked the town of Harawa; armed men in the town fought back, but two of their wounded were captured and taken to the IS base in Nofaliyah, where they were beheaded. 
IS fighters attacked the town of Harawa; armed men in the town fought back, but two of their wounded were captured and taken to the IS base in Nofaliyah, where they were beheaded. 
Authorities in Tripoli detained 172 Tunisians in May in an immigration sweep; they were subsequently freed after pressure from the Tunisian government. Tunisia's consul to Tripoli stated that the arrests were in retaliation for the arrest of a Fajr Libya militia leader at the Tunis airport.
IS launched various attacks on Tripoli-aligned militia in Sirte and at least 23 IS fighters were killed in fighting that included air strikes from Tripoli-aligned planes; Tripoli-aligned Brigade 166 claimed it had gained ground, while IS claimed the opposite.
Government forces launched an air and ground offensive in Benghazi, targeting the district of al-Laithi.
IS claimed responsibility for two suicide bombings: one at a checkpoint near Harawa which killed a militia fighter, and one the next day 60km east of Misrata, which killed 1 fighter and injured 3.

The Libyan air force carried out an air strike on an oil tanker transporting fuel from Greece, which was about to deliver its fuel to a power plant run by the Tripoli-based government.
IS seized the town of Harawa after a weeklong seige; IS fighters then met with local officials to negotiate access to the town and its mosques.
Gunmen attacked Prime Minister al-Thinni's motorcade on the way to the Tobruk airport, wounding one guard; prior to the attack, armed men had protested outside the House of Representatives and attempted to storm the building, firing shots in the air and calling for the removal of al-Thinni from office.
IS took control over the Sirte airport after Fajr Libya troops withdrew from it.
IS claimed a car suicide bombing that killed 5 fighters of Fajr Libya at a checkpoint at the Dafniya entrance to Misrata.
IS attacked a militia checkpoint at near the town of Abu Grain and captured and later killed 3 Misrata militia.
IS seized the last Fajr Libya-controlled areas of Sirte and took over the city, including a militia compound on the road to Misrata.
Government air forces targeted a Dernah courthouse that is a base for IS religious police, but missed and hit a house, killing at least 5 civilians.
The Shura Council of Darna's Jihadis attacked IS in response to the killing of their ledaer, Nasser Akr, by masked gunmen; 9 IS fighters and 2 jihadi fighters were killed in the fighting.
An armed militia entered the Tunisian consulate and abducted 10 staff members; the militia freed 3 captives after 5 days and the rest after one week.
Dozens of IS fighters were killed in fighting over the course of a week as the Mujahedeen Council of Derna launched an offensive to remove IS from Derna.
The US military carried out an air strike on a farm south of Ajdabiya and killed at least 17 militants; the strike targeted Al-Mourabitoun leader Mokhtar Balmokhtar, who was presumed dead and led to fighting near the Ajdabiya hospital betweeen the group that was injured and the Libyan military.
The US military carried out an air strike on a farm south of Ajdabiya and killed at least 17 militants; the strike targeted Al-Mourabitoun leader Mokhtar Balmokhtar, who was presumed dead and led to fighting near the Ajdabiya hospital betweeen the group that was injured and the Libyan military.
Government forces launched an offensive in the town of Ain Mara against the Mujahedeen Council of Derna, who occupy the town and are backed by Fajr Libya; 21 loyalists were killed over four days of fighting.
Dozens of people protested outside the National General Congress in Tripoli in opposition to the latest peace proposal; some protesters burned pictures of the UN envoy leading the peace talks. 
At least 10 civilians were killed and at least 15 were wounded when three separate car bombs exploded in Derna; the bombs set off clashes between IS fighters and al-Qaida-linked militias that continued into the next day.
Taher Allush, a senior military intelligence officer algined with Fajr Libya, was killed in Misrata when a bomb hidden in his car exploded.
At least 21 people were killed over several days of fighting and rocket attacks in Benghazi, including 2 loyalist soldiers killed in clashes with armed groups.
The Libyan air force began carrying out air strikes on ships off the coast of Benghazi that were suspected of carrying weapons for armed groups.
IS announced that it had lost control of the city of Derna after several weeks of fighting with the Mujahedeen Council of Derna.
Four Italian construction workers were kidnapped near the ENI oil complex in the Mellitah region; five days later they had not been found and the identity of the kidnappers was unknown.
Boat traffickers forced migrants into the hold of a boat headed for Europe and forced them to stay inside as the hold flooded by threatenting them with knives, targeting migrants of African origin; it was etimated that 200 people were trapped inside and drowned when the boat overturned.
IS claimed responsibility for a car bomb that exploded in Derna, killing 9 people and wounding dozens.
After IS assassinated an iman in Sirte, Fajr Libya called for an offensive to take back the city from IS; the result was five days of fighting between IS and local militants and Fajr Libya forces, which carried out air strikes; dozens were killed.
In the wake of more migrant deaths in the Mediterranean, protesters marched in Zuara to call for people not to rent homes to migrant smugglers, who use the homes to house migrants as they wait for the seas to be safe enough to cross.
IS and pro-government fighters clashed in Benghazi over two days; 5 loyalist fighters were killed.
A car bomb exploded outside the Eni offices in Tripoli, wounding 1 and damaging some buildings; no group claimed responsilbility.
IS fighters attacked an army position 8km south of Benghazi, killing at least 3 soldiers; the army responded by chasing the attackers, capturing some weapons and causing some casualties.
A car bomb exploded outside the Al-Habda al-Khadra prison in Tripoli, which destroyed 2 cars but caused no casualties.
Fajr Libya organized protests in Tripoli to encourage the Tripoli parliament to reject the recent draft of the peace accord.
IS attacked the prison at the Mitiga airbase in Tripoli in an attempt to free Muslim detainees; at least 4 fighters and three people in the prison were killed.
The government air force launched air strikes on Benghazi as part of an offensive called Operation Two-Edged Sword; it was condemned by the UN as it came on the eve of the deadline for a peace agreement.
A mortar round fired by Islamist militia killed four children playing soccer and an elderly man; it was suspected that the shell was fired to honor the recent killing of a senior Islamist fighter.
Hundreds gathered in  Benghazi to protest a proposed power-sharing and peace deal put forward by the UN; Islamists fired rockets on the protesters, killing 12 and wounding 39. 
A helicopter carrying two senior officials aligned with the Tripoli government was shot down near Zawiya, killing 19; a representative from the internationally recognised government claimed responsibility for the attack, but this was retracted the next day.
A convoy carrying Serbian embassy employees, including the Serbian ambassador to Libya, was ambushed in Sabratha, and two employees were kidnapped.
16 members of the government's armed forces were killed in Benghazi, most by landmines; officials did not specify which groups the army was fighting, but stated that they had gained control of a military base.
Tripoli authorities detained an Emirati police officer on suspicion of being a spy, and purportedly found him in posession of video from a foreign embassy.
The US carried out an airstrike on an IS command and control center near Darnah, targeting Abu Nabil, a senior IS leader; the Pentagon announced it was "reasonably certain" that Nabil had been killed.
Gunmen including Islamist fighters from the Mujahedeen Council of Derna clashed with IS fighters 20 km south of Derna in attempt to drive IS out of the region; IS announced that it was responsible for a suicide car bomb attack south of the city on the same day.
A car bomb explosion at a checkpoint manned by Tripoli-allied forces killed 6 people and wounded 17.
Warplanes from the Tobruk government launched air strikes on IS positions outside of Sirte, including Ajdabiya, in an attempt to stop IS expansion; a government officer stated that strikes also took place the previous week.
Warplanes from the Tobruk government launched air strikes on IS positions outside of Sirte, including Ajdabiya, in an attempt to stop IS expansion; a government officer stated that strikes also took place the previous week.
Rockets hit the Benghazi suburb of Benina, wounding dozens of civilians; rockets also struck two other residential districts, killing 1 and wounding 3.
An army commander was wounded and five soldiers were killed when they were hit by rocket fire as they advanced on positions held by armed groups.
Hundreds of protesters gathered in Tripoli to call for a rejection of the proposed UN peace deal and to support a separately negotiated deal; the demonstrators were organized by Fajr Libya.
At least eleven people were killed and dozens wounded in fighting between Al-Qaeda affiliate Ansar al-Sharia and armed residents of Ajdabiya.

2003 Sudan Government
Tribes clash in South Darfur.
Student loyal to opposition parties stage a violent protest for student union elections.  They assault and hold hostage several lecturers and students.  They battle with riot police.
20 students riot to demand that their diplomas be upgraded to degrees.
Students riot over deteriorating conditions in their boarding houses and battle with riot police.
Teachers strike over pay delays.
High school students protest a teacher strike by attacking and setting fire to offices of the Blue Nile state's education ministry.

An NGO organizes a march of hundreds of children, calling on the government and the rebels to end the civil war.
Three people are killed in a riot at a Sudanese refugee camp.
Thousands of Sudanese protest Israel's assassination of Hamas leader Sheikh Ahmed Yassin.
About 300 disabled Sudanese protest against Israel's assassination of Hamas leader Sheik Ahmed Yassin.
Students gather to protest against the detention of several of their comrades.  The even escalates and the students torch a building.  The police react by firing indiscriminately into the crowd.
71 imprisoned Islamists stage a hunger strike against their detainment.  They are eventually released on the 17th, although Hassan al-Turabi, an opposition leader, remains on strike until the 25th when he is hospitalized.
LRA rebels wage a campaign of violence against Sudanese villages and are attacked by Ugandan Army.
32 jailed Sudanese Islamists stage a hunger strike against their detention without trail or charge.
Tens of thousands of Sudanese march against foreign intervention in the Darfur crisis.  They denounce a plan by the African Union to deploy peacekeepers, as well as the US.

LRA rebels attack a Sudanese village.

Students at Gezira university riot over disputed student elections.  The university's facilities are spread out among many towns in Gezira State.  Students burn and pillage buildings in Hilaliah and Hassaheisah.

1993 Egypt Government
Thousands of members of the Muslim Brotherhood and other non-violent Muslim fundamentalist organizations protest human rights violations in Bosnia.
Four-hundred and twenty Ukrainian sailors go on strike aboard their boat in the port of Alexandria in protest of not having been paid in two months.
Students and citizens hold numerous demonstrations throughout Cairo in protest of the Hebron massacre and the Egyptian government's unsatisfactory response.
Members of the Lawyers' Syndicate engage in strikes and later hold an organized demonstration in protest of the death of a colleague who died in police custody.
3000 workers at a state textile factory go on strike to protest the non-payment of bonuses and allowances for months and to support 2,000 colleagues who had been laid off or moved to administrative positions.
Twenty writers and intellectuals demonstrate in protest of the (non-lethal) stabbing of Nobel Prize-winning author Naguib Mahfouz by Islamic radicals and the government's failure to stand up for intellectual freedom.
Tens of thousands of people left homeless by torrential rains in southern Egypt demonstrate, demanding government assistance; in the town of Durunka.

Arab Spring.  A man self-immolates in front of the Egyptian parliament.  Another self-immolates in Alexandria.  This is the first such event in Egypt following the revolution in Tunisia.
Arab Spring.  A man self-immolates in front of the Egyptian parliament.  Another self-immolates in Alexandria.  This is the first such event in Egypt following the revolution in Tunisia.
Arab Spring.  The 2011 Egyptian Revolution.  An uprising triggered by lack of jobs, food prices, and authoritarianism.  The uprising features marches, riots, sit-ins, and strikes.  Police and military forces respond with deadly force.
Arab Spring.  Mass prison escapes occur during the revolution.  Soldiers arrest or kill a large number of the escapees.

Protesters marched, then rioted in several cities after President Morsi  claimed emergency powers until a new constitution was finished, and declared his decisions exempt from judicial review. Several Muslim Brotherhood offices were stormed and set aflame, and Protesters clashed with Islamists and security forces alike. Protests continued after it became apparent that the proposed new constitution was largely a product of Islamists, and could infringe basic freedoms.
